clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Efavirenz-based Regimen in HIV-1-infected Patients With Nevirapine Hypersensitivity
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Virological and Immunological Results of Efavirenz-based Regimen in HIV-infected Patients With or Without Allergic Reactions to Nevirapine

collaborator.agency: Thai Red Cross AIDS Research Centre

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to compare the effectiveness of EFV-based regimens in HIV-1-infected patients who; (1) were previously allergic to NVP and stopped all ARV simultaneously; (2) were previously allergic to NVP and continued the other NRTIs for a period of time, i.e. "staggered interruption"; and (3) started EFV-based regimens as an initial regimen (as controlled group).

primary_outcome.description: Virological failure was defined as either (1) two consecutive results of plasma HIV-1 RNA >400 copies/ml or (2) plasma HIV-1 RNA >1,000 copies/ml with genotypic resistance assay revealed NRTI or NNRTI resistance-associated mutations

secondary_outcome.description: Virological suppression was defined as having plasma HIV-1 RNA <50 copies/ml

secondary_outcome.measure: Median increase from baseline of CD4 cell count

secondary_outcome.description: Adverse events were defined as either (1) having more than grade 3 according to DAID AE Grading Table, or (2) having clinical events that leaded to changed antiretroviral medications

secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical outcomes such as death, major opportunistic infections, immune recovery syndrome, non-AIDS events

arm_group.description: stopped all drugs in NNRTI-based regimens simultaneously after allergic reactions to NVP-based regimens, and later started EFV-based regimens
HIV-1-infected patients who started EFV-based regimens as their initial ARV regimens.
after having allergic reactions to NVP-based regimens, stopped NNRTIs first, continued the other NRTIs for a period of time, i.e. "staggered interruption", and later started EFV-based regimens

intervention.description: Efavienz: 600 mg, oral, every 24 hours, continued medication until the end of study.

study_pop.textblock: HIV-infected patients who started EFV-based regimens between January 2002 and December 2008 at Bamrasnaradura Infectious Diseases Institute

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- age 18-70 years old
- documented HIV infection
- started EFV-based regimens between January 2002 and December 2008 at Bamrasnaradura Infectious Diseases Institute
Exclusion Criteria:
- previously received non-HAART regimens such as dual NRTIs regimen, AZT monotherapy with single-dose NVP in pregnancy patients
- previously received protease inhibitor-based regimen
- diseases or conditions that significantly affected either kidney or liver functions such as decompensated liver cirrhosis, ESRD
